text: Laws (Ancient Greek Νόμοι Nómoi ['nɔmɔɪ̯]) is a text Plato wrote as an old man. Like most of his other works, it is written in the form of a dialogue. It is perhaps Plato's most important writing. In the dialogue, three people on a hiking trip discuss what an ideal state should look like. They discuss many topics and questions, including these: * Divine revelation, divine law and law-giving * The role of intelligence in law-giving * The relations of philosophy, religion, and politics * The role of music, exercise and dance in education * Natural law and natural rights Category:Works by Plato
title: Laws (Plato)
